GraphLib package¶

Submodules¶

GraphLib.DirectedGraph module¶

class GraphLib.DirectedGraph.DirectedGraph(name='')¶

Bases: object

The class that implements a directed Graph.

It’s also the base class of all other Graphs.

addArc(origin, target)¶

Add an arc to the Graph. If a vertex of the new arc does not belong to the Graph, it is added to the Graph. If the arc already belong to the graph, a message is written but nothing is done.

addVertex(n)¶

Add a vertex to the graph. The resulting vertex is not connected to any other node of the Graph. If the vertex already belongs to the graph, a message is written but nothing is done.

arcToDotString(origin, target)¶

Produce the string corresponding to an arc in a .dot file in the context of this type of graph.

for directed graphs it takes the form : “origin -> target ;”

getNeighbors(v)¶

Get the list of direct neighbors from vertex v

getPath(start, end, previous)¶

Most graph search returns a collection of recorded path from a certain vertex start to all accessible vertices (except in the case of early exit). These recorded paths can be implemented as a dictionnary called previous

previous : a dictionnary that contains all recorded paths. Each vertex accessible k is a key in the dictionnary. The value v associated to k is the vertex from which one should arrive to reach k

Hence, one can retrieve a path from start to any vertex end accessible by going backward in previous from end to its previous vertex and iterate until start is found.

returns a list of vertices found along the path from start to end

getPrevious(v)¶

Get the list of vertices that have v as a direct neighbor

printPath(path)¶

A path is a list of vertices. This function simply print every vertex in the path.

No verification is made that the list of vertices is really a path in the graph (the vertices should be successive neighbors).

runBreadthFirst(start)¶

The BreadthFirstSearch Algorithm : It will make a search of all accessible vertices, starting at vertex start.

returns previous : a dictionnary that contains all recorded paths. Each vertex accessible k is a key in the dictionnary. The value v associated to k is the vertex from which one should arrive to reach k

Hence, one can retrieve a path from start to any vertex a accessible by going backward in previous from a to its previous vertex and iterate until start is found. This is done by the getPath method

toDot(filename=None)¶

Produce a .dot output, as in the graphviz Library. If a filename is given, the method will save the produced string in a file. If not, it will be printed.

toDotString()¶

Produce the string corresponding to a .dot output, as in the graphviz Library.

GraphLib.UndirectedGraph module¶

class GraphLib.UndirectedGraph.UndirectedGraph(name='')¶

Bases: GraphLib.DirectedGraph.DirectedGraph

The class that implements an undirected Graph.

It is basically a directed Graph with symetrical arcs.

addArc(origin, target)¶

Add an undirected arc to the Graph. If a vertex of the new arc does not belong to the Graph, it is added to the Graph. If the arc already belong to the graph, a message is written but nothing is done.

addVertex(n)¶

Add a vertex to the graph. The resulting vertex is not connected to any other node of the Graph. If the vertex already belongs to the graph, a message is written but nothing is done.

arcToDotString(origin, target)¶

Produce the string corresponding to a an arc in a .dot file in the context of this type of graph.

for undirected graphs it takes the form : “origin – target ;”

getNeighbors(v)¶

Get the list of direct neighbors from vertex v

getPath(start, end, previous)¶

Most graph search returns a collection of recorded path from a certain vertex start to all accessible vertices (except in the case of early exit). These recorded paths can be implemented as a dictionnary called previous

previous : a dictionnary that contains all recorded paths. Each vertex accessible k is a key in the dictionnary. The value v associated to k is the vertex from which one should arrive to reach k

Hence, one can retrieve a path from start to any vertex end accessible by going backward in previous from end to its previous vertex and iterate until start is found.

returns a list of vertices found along the path from start to end

getPrevious(v)¶

Get the list of vertices that have v as a direct neighbor

printPath(path)¶

A path is a list of vertices. This function simply print every vertex in the path.

No verification is made that the list of vertices is really a path in the graph (the vertices should be successive neighbors).

runBreadthFirst(start)¶

The BreadthFirstSearch Algorithm : It will make a search of all accessible vertices, starting at vertex start.

returns previous : a dictionnary that contains all recorded paths. Each vertex accessible k is a key in the dictionnary. The value v associated to k is the vertex from which one should arrive to reach k

Hence, one can retrieve a path from start to any vertex a accessible by going backward in previous from a to its previous vertex and iterate until start is found. This is done by the getPath method

toDot(filename=None)¶

Produce a .dot output, as in the graphviz Library. If a filename is given, the method will save the produced string in a file. If not, it will be printed.

toDotString(filename=None)¶

Produce the string corresponding to a .dot output, as in the graphviz Library.

It overrides the method of DirectedGraph since it’s quite different.

GraphLib.WeightedDirectedGraph module¶

class GraphLib.WeightedDirectedGraph.WeightedDirectedGraph(name='')¶

Bases: GraphLib.DirectedGraph.DirectedGraph

The class that implements an weighted directed Graph.

It is basically a directed Graph where arcs have weights

addArc(origin, target, weight=1.0)¶

Add a weighted arc to the Graph.

If a vertex of the new arc does not belong to the Graph, it is added to the Graph. If the arc already belong to the graph, a message is written but nothing is done.

addVertex(n)¶

Add a vertex to the graph. The resulting vertex is not connected to any other node of the Graph. If the vertex already belongs to the graph, a message is written but nothing is done.

arcToDotString(origin, target)¶

Produce the string corresponding to a an arc in a .dot file in the context of this type of graph.

for weighted directed graphs it takes the form :
“origin -> target [ label = “weight” ] ;”
getArcWeight(origin, target)¶

get the weight of an arc in the graph

If the arc does not belong to the graph, a key Exception is raised

getMinDistance_(toDo, distances)¶

An intern function for the Diskstra Algorithm : it looks in the toDo list which vertex is the closest to start

Parameters:
  • toDo – the list of vertices to examine
  • distances – a dictionnary of distances (usually to start vertex) - the key is a vertex v - the value is the distance from start to v
Returns:

minVertex: the vertex in toDo with the smallest distance.
getNeighbors(v)¶

Get the list of direct neighbors from vertex v

getPath(start, end, previous)¶

Most graph search returns a collection of recorded path from a certain vertex start to all accessible vertices (except in the case of early exit). These recorded paths can be implemented as a dictionnary called previous

previous : a dictionnary that contains all recorded paths. Each vertex accessible k is a key in the dictionnary. The value v associated to k is the vertex from which one should arrive to reach k

Hence, one can retrieve a path from start to any vertex end accessible by going backward in previous from end to its previous vertex and iterate until start is found.

returns a list of vertices found along the path from start to end

getPrevious(v)¶

Get the list of vertices that have v as a direct neighbor

printPath(path)¶

A path is a list of vertices. This function simply print every vertex in the path.

No verification is made that the list of vertices is really a path in the graph (the vertices should be successive neighbors).

runBreadthFirst(start)¶

The BreadthFirstSearch Algorithm : It will make a search of all accessible vertices, starting at vertex start.

returns previous : a dictionnary that contains all recorded paths. Each vertex accessible k is a key in the dictionnary. The value v associated to k is the vertex from which one should arrive to reach k

Hence, one can retrieve a path from start to any vertex a accessible by going backward in previous from a to its previous vertex and iterate until start is found. This is done by the getPath method

runDijkstra(start)¶

The Diskstra Algorithm : It will make a search of all accessible vertices, starting at vertex start and compute the smallest path to all of them, taking the weights of arcs into account.

Parameters:start – the starting vertex of the search.
Returns:(previous, distances) - previous : a dictionnary that contains all recorded paths. Each vertex accessible k is a key in the dictionnary. The value v associated to k is the vertex from which one should arrive to reach k - distances : a dictionnary of the distance from start to every accessible vertex in the graph.
  • the key is a vertex v
  • the value is the distance from start to v

Hence, one can retrieve a path from start to any vertex a accessible by going backward in previous from a to its previous vertex and iterate until start is found. This is done by the getPath method

Warning

The search for a current vertex to explore is not at all optimal in the current implementation. A priority queue should be used instead.

toDot(filename=None)¶

Produce a .dot output, as in the graphviz Library. If a filename is given, the method will save the produced string in a file. If not, it will be printed.

toDotString()¶

Produce the string corresponding to a .dot output, as in the graphviz Library.

GraphLib.WeightedUndirectedGraph module¶

class GraphLib.WeightedUndirectedGraph.WeightedUndirectedGraph(name='', filename=None)¶

Bases: GraphLib.UndirectedGraph.UndirectedGraph

The class that implements an weighted undirected Graph.

It is basically an undirected Graph where arcs have weights

addArc(origin, target, weight=1.0)¶

Add a weighted arc to the Graph.

If a vertex of the new arc does not belong to the Graph, it is added to the Graph. If the arc already belong to the graph, a message is written but nothing is done.

addVertex(n)¶

Add a vertex to the graph. The resulting vertex is not connected to any other node of the Graph. If the vertex already belongs to the graph, a message is written but nothing is done.

arcToDotString(origin, target)¶

Produce the string corresponding to a an arc in a .dot file in the context of this type of graph.

for weighted undirected graphs it takes the form :
“origin – target [ label = “weight” ] ;”

get the weight of an arc in the graph

If the arc does not belong to the graph, a key Exception is raised

Produce the string corresponding to a .dot output, as in the graphviz Library.
